dt: used to indicate that you are saying something by using only one word or by using as few words as possible

dt.t: Our answer, {it}in a word{/it}, is no.

dt: used to introduce a statement that repeats what has been said in a different and usually a simpler or more exact way

shortdef: the practice of improving the educational and job opportunities of members of groups that have not been treated fairly in the past because of their race, sex, etc. —called also (British) positive discrimination

def: {it}US{/it}, {it}law{/it} {bc} a lawsuit in which many people join together to sue because they all say they were harmed by the same person or group

dt: {bc}a lawsuit in which many people join together to sue because they all say they were harmed by the same person or group

utxt.t: a {it}class-action{/it} suit against a car company

shortdef: a lawsuit in which many people join together to sue because they all say they were harmed by the same person or group

def: {it}British{/it}

shortdef: job action

def: {it}US{/it} {bc} something (such as a strike or a slowing of work) done by workers to protest bad conditions, low wages, etc.

dt: {bc}something (such as a strike or a slowing of work) done by workers to protest bad conditions, low wages, etc.

dt.t: The union has threatened a {it}job action{/it} if wages are not increased.

shortdef: something (such as a strike or a slowing of work) done by workers to protest bad conditions, low wages, etc. —called also (British) industrial action

def: {bc} a movie or scene in which actors and sets are used {bc} a movie or scene that is not produced by animation

dt: {bc}a movie or scene in which actors and sets are used {bc}a movie or scene that is not produced by animation

dt.t: a combination of {it}live action{/it} and animation

shortdef: a movie or scene in which actors and sets are used : a movie or scene that is not produced by animation
